Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Story:
I sat on the edge of my bed, phone buzzing in my hand. My stepbrother’s text glowed on the screen: “Can you come over? I really need you.” He’d just found out his dad was sick again, and I knew he was barely holding it together. As his step-sister, I was supposed to be there, to listen, to help him through the worst of it. But my phone vibrated again—this time, it was my boyfriend. “We need to talk. I can’t keep fighting about money. Can you come over?” We’d argued three times this week, and I could feel the tension building, threatening to break us apart if I didn’t try to fix things soon.

My heart pounded as I stared at the two messages. Both needed me, both expected me to show up, to be present, to help. I felt torn in two, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I turned. I wanted to be the supportive sister, but I also wanted to be the girlfriend who didn’t run away from problems. My hands shook as I tried to decide who needed me more, and who I would let down tonight.
